State.numePart8: No FIT Match Next State Number
State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter the card. While the terminal is waiting for card entry, this screen is displayed.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes: \r\n1. Following a good read of the card if FITs are not used (Table entry 9 = 000) \r\nor 2. If the Financial Institution number on the card matches a Financial Institution number in a FIT.
State.descriprionPart3: If the read conditions are not satisfied due to a bad card or a mechanism error, the card is ejected and this screen is displayed.
State.descriprionPart4: These three entries specify which card track(s)and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are shown below this table.
State.descriprionPart5: These three entries specify which card track(s)and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are shown below this table.
State.descriprionPart6: These three entries specify which card track(s)and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are shown below this table.
State.descriprionPart7: Tells the terminal when the card should be returned to the cardholder:\r\n000 - eject the card immediately.\r\n001 - return the card as specified by a Transaction Reply command message.
State.descriprionPart8: State number to which the terminal goes if either the Financial Institution number on the card does not match any FIT, or if the card reader is a smart card reader and the read condition being evaluated has the chip connect bit set (bit 3). If FITs are not used this entry must be 000.

State.numePart6: Local PIN Check Error Screen Number
State.numePart7: Remote PIN Check Next State Number
State.numePart8: Local PIN Check Maximum PIN retries
State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter the PIN the first time. This screen, which is displayed on entering the PIN Entry state, must leave the cardholder screen cursor at the start of the PIN Entry display area. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder does not enter the PIN within the permitted time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the Cancel key before the maximum number of digits specified for the PIN have been entered.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes after verification of a correct PIN entry. A Pre-Set Operation Code Buffer state (clearing the function key buffer before Transaction Selection) usually follows a correct PIN entry.
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the correct PIN has not been entered after the number of attempts allowed by table entry 9. The terminal normally enters a Close state if this occurs.
State.descriprionPart6: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to reenter the PIN. This screen is displayed after each incorrect PIN entry attempt. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed. After the number of re-entry attempts allowed by table entry 9, the terminal enters the state determined by table entry 6.
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes when local PIN verification is not performed.
State.descriprionPart8: Maximum number of incorrect PIN entries allowed before the terminal enters the state determined by table entry 6.

State.descriprionPart1: State number that the terminal enters immediately or after an envelope is presented.
State number to which the terminal goes after presetting the Operation Code buffer.
State.descriprionPart2: Specifies bytes of Operation Code buffer to be cleared to graphic ‘space’. Each bit relates to a byte in the Operation Code buffer. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is cleared. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
State.descriprionPart3: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘C’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘A’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
State.descriprionPart4: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘C’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘B’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
State.descriprionPart5: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘C’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘C’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
State.descriprionPart6: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘D’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘D’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
State.descriprionPart8: State number of the Extension state containing information on how the other operation codes are pre-set.

ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘F’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘F’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘G’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘G’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘H’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘H’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘I’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘I’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that requests the cardholder to choose between transaction types, account names, and so on. This screen must be aligned with the active FDKs, and is displayed when the terminal enters the Four FDK Selection Function state. For details, see the “C – Cardholder Display” section in Chapter 3, “Screen Data”.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder does not respond to the screen message within the permitted time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the Cancel key is pressed.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart6: State number to which the terminal goes if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart8:
Defines the Operation Code buffer byte in which the keycode for the selected FDK is stored.
Entry Value - Position in Buffer
‘000’ - 1st byte
‘001 - 2nd byte’
‘002’
‘003’
‘004’
‘005’
‘006’
‘007’ - 8th byte

State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to make an amount entry. This screen is displayed when the terminal enters the Amount Entry state.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the amount entry is not made within the permitted time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the Cancel key is pressed.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart6: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart8: Overlay screen for setting the cardholder screen cursor position. This screen optionally defines the initial display format before amount entry by the cardholder. The cursor should be set on the lefthand side of the echo field on the screen. This is space filled until the required start position for the currency character is reached. For details, see “International Currency Display Format” on page 3-31. The default echo field for eight digits is: bbbbb$b0.00 where b = space. The default echo field for twelve digits is: bbbbbbbbb$b0.00 where b = space.

State.numePart1: Amount Check Condition True Next State Number
State.numePart2: Amount Check Condition False Next State Number
State.descriprionPart1: State number to which the terminal goes when the amount check condition indicated by table entry 8 evaluates to 'true'.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes when the amount check condition indicated by table entry 8 evaluates to 'false'.
State.descriprionPart3:
This field specifies which buffer is to be checked:
000 - Amount buffer
001 - Buffer B.
002 - Buffer C.
If Buffer B or C contains more than 12 digits, the amount check condition evaluates to ‘false’.
State.descriprionPart4: Integer multiple value used in checking specified buffer.\r\nFor example, to check that the specified buffer contains a multiple of the minimum denomination $5, this field would be set to '005'.\r\nThis field is ignored if table entry 8 is not ‘002’.
State.descriprionPart5: Number of decimal places used in specified buffer.\r\nFor example, $5 is sent as 500 cents, so has 002 decimal places.\r\nThis field is ignored if table entry 8 is ‘000’.
State.descriprionPart6: Currency type of amount in specified buffer. Used in conjunction with the Dispenser Currency Cassette Mapping Table.\r\nThis field is ignored if table entry 8 is not ‘003’.
State.descriprionPart7:
Amount check condition required.
If the condition being checked evaluates to 'true' then processing will proceed to the next state identified in table entry 2; otherwise processing will proceed to the next state identified in table entry 3.
All conditions check the buffer indicated by table entry 4, and take account of the decimal point location via the value in table entry 6.
When this entry is set to 000, the state simply evaluates whether the value to the right of the decimal point position is zero.
When this entry is set to 001, the state also evaluates whether the value is zero, or if Buffer B or C contains more than 12 digits.
When this entry is set to 002, the state also evaluates whether the value is a whole number multiple of the value identified in table entry 5.
When this entry is set to 003, the state evaluates whether the value is dispensable by the terminal, taking into account the Dispenser Currency Cassette Mapping Table entries, currency type required (table entry 7), the currency type denominations available, dispenser status and cassette status.

State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to make an amount entry. This screen is displayed when the terminal enters the Amount Entry state.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the amount entry is not made within the permitted time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the Cancel key is pressed.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart6: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area. Normally one FDK or touch area is designated for correct amount entries and another for incorrect amount entries. The remaining two FDKs or touch areas are inactive. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ) Enter 255 to deactivate an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart8:
A general-purpose buffer (B or C) is designated for storage. The actual data entered (or ‘X’) to be displayed on the cardholder screen is also defined. The display begins from the current cursor position. Buffer and display parameters are as follows:
000 - Display ‘X’ for each numeric key pressed. Store data in general-purpose buffer C.
001 - Display data as keyed in. Store data in general purpose buffer C.
002 - Display ‘X’ for each numeric key pressed. Store data in general purpose buffer B.
003 - Display data as keyed in. Store data in general purpose buffer B.
See Table Note 5.

State.numePart7: Send PIN Buffer (Buffer A) Data/ Select Extended format
State.numePart8: Send General Purpose Buffer B and/or C or Extension State Number
State.descriprionPart1: Display screen shown on the cardholder screen while the terminal sends a Transaction Request to Central and waits for a Transaction Reply command. This is usually a ‘Please Wait’ screen.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if Central fails to reply to the Transaction Request within the permitted time interval (timer 03).
State.descriprionPart7: See Table Note 6 and Table Note 7.
State.descriprionPart8:
To send the general purpose buffer, the following values apply:
000 - Send no buffers
001 - Send Buffer B.
002 - Send Buffer C
003 - Send Buffers B and C
004-007 - Reserved
If the extended format is selected in table entry 8, this entry is an Extension state number.
See Table Note 8.

ExtensionState.numePart1: Send General Purpose Buffers B and/or C
ExtensionState.descriprionPart1:
To send the general purpose buffers, these values apply:
000 - Send no buffers
001 - Send Buffer B.
002 - Send Buffer C
003 - Send Buffers B and C
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2:
This entry is as for table entry 3 but the data fields are as follows:
 Bit - Field ID
1 - ‘A’(Reserved)
2 - ‘B’(Reserved)
3 - ‘C’
4 - ‘D’
5 - ‘E’
6 - ‘F’
7 - ‘G’
8 - ‘H’
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3:
This entry is as for table entry 3 but the data fields are as follows:
 Bit - Field ID
1 - ‘I’
2 - ‘J’
3 - ‘K’
4 - ‘L’
5 - Reserved for‘M’
6 - Reserved for‘N’
7 - Reserved for‘O’
8 - Reserved for‘P’
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4:
This entry is as for table entry 3 but the data fields are as follows:
 Bit - Field ID
1 - ‘Q’
2 - ‘R’
3 - ‘S’
4 - Reserved for ‘T’
5 - ‘U’
6 - ‘V’
7 - ‘w’
8 - ‘a’
ExtensionState.descriprionPart5:
This entry is as for table entry 3 but the data fields are as follows:
 Bit - Field ID
1 - ‘User Data Fields’
2 - ‘b’ (Notes on escrow counts)
3 - Reserved
4 - Reserved
5 - ‘e’ (Barcode data)
6 - Reserved
7 - Reserved
8 - Reserved
ExtensionState.descriprionPart7: Indicates if EMV CAM processing is to be performed, as follows:\r\n000 - Do not perform EMV CAM processing (default).\r\n001 - Perform EMV CAM processing.

State.descriprionPart1:
Screen displayed on entry to the Close state. This is only displayed if a receipt is delivered in the Close state and the terminal has not been instructed by the last Transaction Reply message to capture the card. The last Transaction Reply Command performed determines the screen text as follows:
Card Before Cash - ‘Take cash and receipt’
Fast Cash - ‘Take card, cash and receipt’
Other Commands - ‘Take card and receipt’
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes after the state is completed.
State.descriprionPart3:
Screen displayed on entry to the Close state. This is only displayed if no receipt is delivered in the Close state and the terminal has not been instructed by the last Transaction Reply message to capture the card. The last Transaction Reply Command performed determines the screen text as follows:
Card Before Cash - ‘Take cash’
Fast Cash - ‘Take cash and card’
Other Commands - ‘Take card’
State.descriprionPart4: Screen displayed on entry to the Close state, informing the cardholder that the card has been retained. This is only displayed if the terminal has been instructed by the last Transaction Reply message to capture the card during the Close state. This screen is also displayed for four seconds if the card is captured due to timer 09 expiring (card not taken).
State.descriprionPart5: Display screen to be overlaid when either the receipt is delivered (entry 2) or there is no receipt delivery (entry 4). This screen is only displayed if the statement is cut and delivered in a Close state and the terminal has not been instructed by the last Transaction Reply message to capture the card.
State.descriprionPart7: Screen displayed on entry to the Close state, informing the cardholder that the Bunch Note Acceptor (BNA) notes are being returned.
State.descriprionPart8: State number of the optional Extension state. See Table Note 10.

ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: Screen number required for the error recovery actions which may take place in this state if the CPM is present.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: This flag controls the error recovery actions which may take place in this state if the CPM is present. See Table Note 11.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart7: This flag controls the error recovery actions which may take place in this state if the BNA is present. See Table Note 12.

State.descriprionPart1: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart2: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart3: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart4: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart5: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart6: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart7: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart8: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)

ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart5: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart6: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart7: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart8: State number of the mandatory Extension state.

ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart1: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart2: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart3: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart4: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart5: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart6: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart7: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
ExtensionExtensionState.descriprionPart8: State to which the terminal goes depending on the next state index stored in the FIT. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)

State.numePart4: No Write Attempted Next State Number
State.descriprionPart1: Screen displayed during a Card Write operation.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes after a satisfactory Track write operation.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the Track write is unsuccessful.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if no data or invalid data is present in the Track buffer. This state is also used if a start and/or end sentinel is missing, or the Track data buffers are too long.

State.numePart4: Local PIN Check Good PIN Next State Number
State.numePart5: Local PIN Check Maximum Bad PINs Next State Number
State.numePart6: Local PIN Check Error Screen Number
State.numePart7: Remote PIN Check Next State Number
State.numePart8: Local PIN Check Maximum PIN Check Retries
State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter the PIN the first time. This screen is displayed on entering the PIN Entry state. It must leave the cursor at the start of the PIN Entry display area. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder does not enter the PIN within the permitted time limit. Enter state number 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the Cancel key before the maximum number of digits specified for the PIN have been entered.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes after verification of a correct PIN entry. A Pre-Set Operation Code buffer state (clearing the function key buffer before Transaction Selection) usually follows a correct PIN entry. See Table Note 15.
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the correct PIN has not been entered after the number of attempts allowed by table entry 9. This could be a Card Write state in order to update the Track 3 PIN retry field. See Table Note 13, Table Note 14, and Table Note 15.
State.descriprionPart6: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to reenter the PIN. This screen is displayed after each incorrect PIN entry attempt. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed. After the number of re-entry attempts allowed by table entry 9, the terminal enters the state determined by table entry 6. See Table Note 13 and Table Note 15.
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes when local PIN verification is not performed.
State.descriprionPart8: Maximum number of incorrect PIN entries before the terminal enters the state determined by table entry 6. This entry is used as the PIN retry count if the PIN retry count is not on the card (FIT entry PRCNT = FF). See Table Note 13 and Table Note 15.

State.descriprionPart1: Number of display screen prompting an amount entry.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder fails to enter the amount within the specified time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the Cancel key.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the specified FDK. Normally one FDK is used to specify whether the amount entry is correct and another to specify incorrect. The other keys are inactive. Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the specified FDK. Normally one FDK is used to specify whether the amount entry is correct and another to specify incorrect. The other keys are inactive. Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart6: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the specified FDK. Normally one FDK is used to specify whether the amount entry is correct and another to specify incorrect. The other keys are inactive. Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the specified FDK. Normally one FDK is used to specify whether the amount entry is correct and another to specify incorrect. The other keys are inactive. Enter 255 to deactivate any FDK or touch area. (Base 10 range 000-254 or 256-999) (Base 36 range 000-254 or 256-ZZZ)
State.descriprionPart8: State number of the Extension state.

ExtensionState.descriprionPart1:
This field determines which buffer the amount entered will be stored in:
000 - Amount buffer
001 - Buffer B.
002 - Buffer C
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: Overlay screen for setting the cursor position on the cardholder screen. This screen optionally defines the initial display format before amount entry by the cardholder. The cursor should be set on the left-hand side of the echo field on the screen. This is space filled until the required start position for the currency character is reached. For details, see “International Currency Display Format” on page 3-31.\r\nThe default echo field for eight digits is: bbbb$b0.00 where b = space.\r\nThe default echo field for twelve digits is: bbbbbbbb$b0.00 where b = space.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: This flag determines if the screen defined in table entry 3 of this extension state is language dependent:\r\n000 - Not language dependent\r\n001 - Language dependent, regardless of language group size.

State.numePart1: No Language Code Next State Number
State.descriprionPart1: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is illegal or cannot be read.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 0.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 1.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 2.
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 3.
State.descriprionPart6: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 4.
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 5.
State.descriprionPart8: State number of the Extension state containing the next states for language codes 6-9.\r\nA value of 255 means that there is no Extension state, and language codes 6-9 cause the No Language Code next state exit to be taken.

ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 6.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 7.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 8.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the language code is 9.

State.descriptionType: Card Read - PIN Entry Initiation State
State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter a card. While the terminal is waiting for a card entry, this screen will be displayed.
State.descriprionPart2:
State nu mber to which the terminal goes:
1. Following a good read of the card if FITs are not used (Table Entry 3 in Extension state = 000)
or
2. If the Financial Institution number on the card matches a Financial Institution number in a FIT.
State.descriprionPart3: Screen that is displayed if an unsuccessful read occurs; or for a DASH card, the cardholder fails to take the card before timer 72 expires.
State.descriprionPart4: These three entries specify which card track(s) and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are the same as for the ‘A’ Card Read state in Table 2-4 on page 2-7.
State.descriprionPart5: These three entries specify which card track(s) and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are the same as for the ‘A’ Card Read state in Table 2-4 on page 2-7.
State.descriprionPart6: These three entries specify which card track(s) and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are the same as for the ‘A’ Card Read state in Table 2-4 on page 2-7.
State.descriprionPart7: This field is not used. The early card eject feature is not supported by this state. The card is always returned as specified by the Transaction Reply command message.
State.descriprionPart8: State number of the Extension state containing information for parallel PIN entry.

ExtensionState.numePart2: No FIT Match Next State Number
ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter a PIN. This screen is displayed on card entry. The identified screen must leave the cursor positioned at the beginning of the PIN Entry display area. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed. The Track 1 name cannot be displayed at this time because the card has not been read.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the Financial Institution number on the card does not match any FIT. If FITs are not used, this entry must be 000. The No FIT match exit is also taken if the SST has a DASH reader and one of the chip connect bits is set and the ATR succeeds.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: A binary encoded value which specifies the FDKs or touch areas that are active as Clear keys during PIN entry. Each bit relates to an FDK or touch area. Bit 0 relates to FDK ‘A’ (or FDK ‘A’ touch area); bit 7 relates to FDK ‘I’ (or FDK ‘I’ touch area). If a bit is ‘1’, the relative FDK or touch area is active. If a bit is ‘0’, the relative FDK or touch area is inactive. See Table Note 17.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: A binary encoded value which specifies the FDKs or touch areas that are active as Accept keys during PIN entry. Each bit relates to an FDK or touch area. Bit 0 relates to FDK ‘A’ (or FDK ‘A’ touch area); bit 7 relates to FDK ‘I’ (or FDK ‘I’ touch area). If a bit is ‘1’, the relative FDK or touch area is active. If a bit is ‘0’, the relative FDK or touch area is inactive. See Table Note 17.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart5: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to remove the card and wait - if the card reader is a DASH card reader, and a chip connect bit is set, but the ATR fails. This screen is displayed until the cardholder removes the card or timer 72 expires.

State.descriprionPart1: State number to which the terminal goes after selecting the screen group.
State.descriprionPart2: Decimal number in the range 0-9 identifying the code for screen group 1.
State.descriprionPart3: Decimal number in the range 0-9 identifying the code for screen group 2.
State.descriprionPart4: Decimal number in the range 0-9 identifying the code for screen group 3.
State.descriprionPart5: Decimal number in the range 0-9 identifying the code for screen group 4.
State.descriprionPart6: Decimal number in the range 0-9 identifying the code for screen group 5.
State.descriprionPart7: Decimal number in the range 0-9 identifying the code for screen group 6.
State.descriprionPart8: Number of screens in each language group. To specify 1000 screens, set this to 001.

State.descriprionPart1: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart5: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart6: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart7: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer
State.descriprionPart8: State number to which the terminal goes depending on the key code stored in the FDK buffer

State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts key selection by cardholder.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder fails to respond to the message within the permitted time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the Cancel key is pressed.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if an FDK or touch area is pressed.
State.descriprionPart5: State number of Extension state containing assigned values for the eight FDKs or touch areas.
State.descriprionPart6:
Identifies which buffer is to be edited and the number of zeros to add to the values specified in the Extension state:
01X - General purpose buffer B.
02X - General purpose buffer C
03X - Amount buffer. See Table Note 19.
X specifies the number of zeros in the range 0-9
State.descriprionPart7: Specifies the FDKs or touch areas that are active during this state. Each bit relates to an FDK or touch area. Bit 0 relates to FDK ‘A’ (or FDK ‘A’ touch area); bit 7 relates to FDK ‘I’ (or FDK ‘I’ touch area). If a bit is ‘1’ the relative FDK or touch area is active. If a bit is ‘0’ the relative FDK or touch area is inactive. See Table Note 18.

ExtensionState.numePart1: Value stored if FDK ‘A’\r\n or FDK ‘A’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart2: Value stored if FDK ‘B’\r\n or FDK ‘B’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart3: Value stored if FDK ‘C’\r\n or FDK ‘C’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart4: Value stored if FDK ‘D’\r\n or FDK ‘D’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart5: Value stored if FDK ‘F’\r\n or FDK ‘F’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart6: Value stored if FDK ‘G’\r\n or FDK ‘G’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart7: Value stored if FDK ‘H’\r\n or FDK ‘H’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.numePart8: Value stored if FDK ‘I’\r\n or FDK ‘I’ touch area pressed
ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart5: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart6: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart7: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)
ExtensionState.descriprionPart8: Each table entry contains a value that is stored in the buffer specified in the associated FDK Information Entry state table (table entry 7) if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. (Range 000-999 or 000-ZZZ)

State.numePart8: Multi-Language Screens Selection Extension State Number
State.descriprionPart1: Display screen that prompts key selection by the cardholder.
State.descriprionPart2: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder does not respond to the message within the specified time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.
State.descriprionPart3: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the Cancel key.
State.descriprionPart4: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses an FDK or touch area.
State.descriprionPart5: State number of Extension state containing assigned operation codes for the eight FDKs or touch areas. If there is no Extension state, enter 255.
State.descriprionPart6: If there is no Extension state, this defines the Operation Code buffer position to be edited by a value in the range ‘000’ to ‘007’.\r\nIf there is an Extension state, this specifies three bytes of the Operation Code buffer to be set to the values specified in the Extension state. Three numeric values, each in the range ‘0’ to ‘7’, are specified to define three positions in the 8 byte Operation Code buffer to be edited. These three values must be ordered to correspond with the edit characters in the Extension state. If no buffer positions or fewer than three buffer positions are to be edited, this is specified in the Extension state.
State.descriprionPart7: Specifies the FDKs or touch areas that are active during this state. Each bit relates to an FDK or touch area. Bit 0 relates to FDK ‘A’ (or FDK ‘A’ touch area); bit 7 relates to FDK ‘I’ (or FDK ‘I’ touch area). If a bit is ‘1’ the relative FDK or touch area is active. If a bit is ‘0’ the relative FDK or touch area is inactive. See Table Note 20.
State.descriprionPart8: If the state selects the multi-language screen base, this contains the Extension state number. If there is no Extension state, enter 000 or 255.

ExtensionState.numePart1: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘A’\r\n or FDK ‘A’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart2: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘B’\r\n or FDK ‘B’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart3: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘C’\r\n or FDK ‘C’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart4: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘D’\r\n or FDK ‘D’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart5: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘F’\r\n or FDK ‘F’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart6: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘G’\r\n or FDK ‘G’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart7: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘H’\r\n or FDK ‘H’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.numePart8: Operation Code stored if FDK ‘I’\r\n or FDK ‘I’ touch area is pressed.
ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart5: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart6: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart7: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21
ExtensionState.descriprionPart8: Each table entry contains the Operation Code characters to be written to the Operation Code buffer if the specified FDK or touch area is pressed. Three characters are specified for each code, which must be in the range ‘A’ - ‘I’. They are written, in order, to the three positions specified in the associated Eight FDK Selection Function state table (table entry 7). Enter ‘@’ if no character is to be written to a specified position in the buffer.\r\nSee Table Note 21

ExtensionState.numePart1: Screen Base if FDK ‘A’\r\n or FDK ‘A’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart2: Screen Base if FDK ‘B’\r\n or FDK ‘B’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart3: Screen Base if FDK ‘C’\r\n or FDK ‘C’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart4: Screen Base if FDK ‘D’\r\n or FDK ‘D’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart5: Screen Base if FDK ‘F’\r\n or FDK ‘F’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart6: Screen Base if FDK ‘G’\r\n or FDK ‘G’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart7: Screen Base if FDK ‘H’\r\n or FDK ‘H’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.numePart8: Screen Base if FDK ‘I’\r\n or FDK ‘I’ touch area is pressed
ExtensionState.descriprionPart1: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart2: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart3: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart4: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart5: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart6: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart7: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22
ExtensionState.descriprionPart8: Each table entry contains the screen number of the first screen of each language group. The initial base is 000, and all unused fields should contain this value.\r\nSee Table Note 22

Part3.name: Screen Number
Part3.description: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter the card. While the terminal is waiting for card entry, this screen is displayed.

Part4.name: Good Read Next State Number
Part4.description: State number to which the terminal goes: \r\n1. Following a good read of the card if FITs are not used (Table entry 9 = 000) \r\nor 2. If the Financial Institution number on the card matches a Financial Institution number in a FIT.

Part5.name: Error (Misread) Screen Number
Part5.description: If the read conditions are not satisfied due to a bad card or a mechanism error, the card is ejected and this screen is displayed.

Part6.name: Read Condition 1
Part6.description: These three entries specify which card track(s)and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are shown below this table.

Part7.name: Read Condition 2
Part7.description: These three entries specify which card track(s)and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are shown below this table.

Part8.name: Read Condition 3
Part8.description: These three entries specify which card track(s)and/or chip data will be read. The possible values for these entries are shown below this table.

Part9.name: Card Return Flag
Part9.description: Tells the terminal when the card should be returned to the cardholder:\r\n000 - eject the card immediately.\r\n001 - return the card as specified by a Transaction Reply command message.

Part10.name: No FIT Match Next State Number
Part10.description: State number to which the terminal goes if either the Financial Institution number on the card does not match any FIT, or if the card reader is a smart card reader and the read condition being evaluated has the chip connect bit set (bit 3). If FITs are not used this entry must be 000.

Part3.name: Screen number
Part3.description: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to enter the PIN the first time. This screen, which is displayed on entering the PIN Entry state, must leave the cardholder screen cursor at the start of the PIN Entry display area. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed.

Part4.name: Time-Out Next State Number
Part4.description: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder does not enter the PIN within the permitted time limit. Enter 255 if the time-out function is not required.

Part5.name: Cancel Next State Number
Part5.description: State number to which the terminal goes if the cardholder presses the Cancel key before the maximum number of digits specified for the PIN have been entered.

Part6.name: Local PIN Check Good PIN
Part6.description: State number to which the terminal goes after verification of a correct PIN entry. A Pre-Set Operation Code Buffer state (clearing the function key buffer before Transaction Selection) usually follows a correct PIN entry.

Part7.name: Local PIN Check Maximum Bad
Part7.description: State number to which the terminal goes if the correct PIN has not been entered after the number of attempts allowed by table entry 9. The terminal normally enters a Close state if this occurs.

Part8.name: Local PIN Check Error Screen Number
Part8.description: Display screen that prompts the cardholder to reenter the PIN. This screen is displayed after each incorrect PIN entry attempt. An ‘X’ is displayed for each key pressed. After the number of re-entry attempts allowed by table entry 9, the terminal enters the state determined by table entry 6.

Part9.name: Remote PIN Check Next State Number
Part9.description: State number to which the terminal goes when local PIN verification is not performed.

Part10.name: Local PIN Check Maximum PIN retries
Part10.description: Maximum number of incorrect PIN entries allowed before the terminal enters the state determined by table entry 6.

Part3.name: Next State Number
Part3.description: State number that the terminal enters immediately or after an envelope is presented.

Part3.name: Next State Number
Part3.description: State number to which the terminal goes after presetting the Operation Code buffer.

Part4.name: Clear Mask
Part4.description: Specifies bytes of Operation Code buffer to be cleared to graphic ‘space’. Each bit relates to a byte in the Operation Code buffer. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is cleared. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part5.name: ‘A’ Pre-Set Mask
Part5.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘C’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘A’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part6.name: ‘B’ Pre-Set Mask
Part6.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘C’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘B’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part7.name: ‘C’ Pre-Set Mask
Part7.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘C’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘C’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part8.name: ‘D’ Pre-Set Mask
Part8.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘D’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘D’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part10.name: Extension State Number
Part10.description: State number of the Extension state containing information on how the other operation codes are pre-set.

Part13.name: ‘F’ Pre-Set Mask
Part13.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘F’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘F’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part14.name: ‘G’ Pre-Set Mask
Part14.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘G’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘G’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part15.name: ‘H’ Pre-Set Mask
Part15.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘H’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘H’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.

Part16.name: ‘I’ Pre-Set Mask
Part16.description: The buffer contains eight bytes. This entry sets the specified bytes to ‘I’. If a bit is one, the corresponding entry is set to ‘I’. If a bit is zero, the corresponding entry is unchanged. See Table Note 3.
